The total Federal spending at Department of Energy facilities for fiscal years 1995 and 1996 is limited to a certain percentage of the amount appropriated for fiscal year 1993, with specific dollar amounts set as maximum limits. The Reduction in Department of Energy Facility Funding Commission is established to limit funding for Department of Energy facilities after fiscal year 1997 to a certain percentage of the amount appropriated for fiscal year 1993, with annual adjustments for inflation. The Energy Facility Funding Commission must submit a plan to the Secretary within 8 months for implementing funding reductions through contractor reforms, private investment, and eliminating redundancies. If reductions cannot be fully achieved, cutbacks in programs may be proposed. The Energy Facility Funding Commission, appointed by the President, evaluates programs based on relevance, maintains facility abilities, and includes peer review. Members have technical expertise in DOE facility research and represent affected communities. The President appoints the Energy Facility Funding Commission, which evaluates programs at Department of Energy facilities. Nominations for the Commission must be transmitted to the Senate within 2 months of enactment. The President consults with various leaders in selecting Commission members. The Energy Facility Funding Commission is appointed by the President to evaluate programs at Department of Energy facilities. Nominations for the Commission must be sent to the Senate within 2 months. The President consults with leaders for member appointments. The Commission's Chairperson is designated by the President. Each member's term ends when the Commission terminates. Meetings are generally open to the public. The Energy Facility Funding Commission meetings shall be open to the public. Vacancies in the Commission will be filled in the same manner as the original appointment. Members, excluding the Chairperson, will receive pay equal to the minimum annual rate of basic pay for level IV of the Executive Schedule for each day of duty. The Chairperson will also receive compensation for their duties. The Commission shall appoint a Director who has not been a civilian employee of the Department of Energy in the past year. Members will receive pay based on the minimum annual rate of basic pay for level III of the Executive Schedule. Travel expenses will be provided according to specified regulations. The Director shall be paid at the rate of basic pay for level IV of the Executive Schedule. The Director may appoint additional personnel without regard to certain civil service laws. The Director may appoint additional personnel without regard to certain civil service laws. Personnel appointed may be paid without following certain pay rate provisions, with a limitation on personnel from the Department of Energy. Other federal agencies may detail personnel to the Commission upon request from the Director. The Commission may procure temporary or intermittent services of experts or consultants. The Comptroller General of the United States shall provide assistance to the Commission. The Commission has the authority to lease space and acquire property using available funds. They are encouraged to use suitable real property listed by the Resolution Trust Corporation. Funding will be provided as necessary, and the Commission will terminate within 14 months of enactment. The Secretary must report to Congress within 45 days if recommendations from the Commission are not followed, explaining any disagreements. SEC. 2. DEFINITIONS.

    The term "Commission" refers to the Reduction in Department of Energy Facility Funding Commission. 
    The term "Department of Energy facility" includes research and development laboratories, commercialization facilities, and technology replication facilities. 
    The term "Secretary" refers to the Secretary of Energy.

SEC. 3. SENSE OF CONGRESS.

    Congress believes that savings from section 1(a) should be deposited in the Treasury of the United States.
